subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
{{liushu|p}} – fired earthenware pottery, or a tile.

subSections.title: Readings
Etymology 1
subSections.text:
[[Image:Tiled roof in Dubrovnik-edit.jpg|thumb]]
{{ja-kanjitab|かわら|yomi=kun}}

{{IPAchar|/kapara/}} → {{IPAchar|/kaɸara/}} → {{IPAchar|/kawara/}}

Probably from {{der|ja|sa|sort=かわら|कपाल||cup, bowl, skull}},<ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref><ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>  possibly via {{ltc-l|迦波羅|id=2,1,1}}.  Along with Buddhism, roof tiles came to Japan in the {{w|Asuka period}}.

Cognate with {{m|ja|骨}}, {{m|ja|䯊|tr=kawara||a bone, particularly a covering bone such as a skull or kneecap}}.

Folk etymologies include:
* from {{m|ja|変わる|変わら|tr=kawara}}, the {{m|ja|未然形|tr=mizenkei||incomplete form}} of verb {{m|ja|変わる|tr=kawaru||to change}}, from the idea that tiles were produced by changing the clay into pottery through [[firing]]

subSections.title: Etymology 2
subSections.text:
Abbreviation of transliterated {{ja-ateji|sort=くらむ'}} spelling {{ja-r|瓦%蘭%姆|グ%ラ%ム}}, attested in the {{w|Meiji period}}.  The term {{ja-r|グラム}} itself was borrowed from either {{bor|ja|en|gram}} or {{bor|ja|fr|gramme}}.<ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref><ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

Once considered a {{m|ja|国字|tr=kokuji||national character|pos=a kanji coined in Japan}}, another example being {{ja-r|瓲|トン|[[ton]], [[tonne]]}}.
